page.lettertext:
fol.140r
Belgia 1591 May 12
Belgia: 1591: May
S
r
Yowe shall receive at this time a letter from hir
Ma
tie
to
the
Counsell of Estate
in awnsweare to certaine of their letters
written in the ende of the last moneth, for awnsweare to hir
former letters whereof yowe weare acquainted in reproving of
them for their negligence concerning the defence of the towne of
Ostend,
of w
ch
hir Ma
ties
letters nowe sent, yowe shall recieve
hearew
th
a Copie, wherebie yowe maie understand hir Ma
ties
pleisure for yo
r
proceeding in maintena
u
ce of hir former letters
and disproving of their awnsweares as not sufficient, and soe
to continue in declaring of hir Ma
ties
misliking expressed in hir
former letters: And nowe at this time yowe shall perceave that
hir Ma
tie
hath great cawses to increase hir Complaint & offence
for their wilfull permission of their people in sondrie their
portes, both in
Holland
and
Zeland
to use an open [.] not
onelie of all kinde of merchaundise, even as thowgh there weare
noe Enmitie betwixt their Cuntries and
Spaigne,
but also [.]
conveiaunce and provisions of all kinde of munic
o
ns for the warre,
and namelie of powder and Cordage carried into the partes of
Biskaie
and
Gallicia,
and part into
Cales,
and other Sowth
tes
in such sort as if the
King
Navie in Gallicia and Biskaie had
not been nowe this last yeare, and this Springe, furnished therw
th
theie had not been hable to have comen to the se[.] [.]
nor to have comen into
Britaigne,
as theie have done [.]
also theie are nowe releved vearie late by shippes [.]
Cuntries that have browght the like provision [.]
wheareof the P. Donles, being the Frenche [.]
theare in Britaigne, hath made [.]
to hir Ma
tie
pretending that [.]
the low Cuntries might and owght [.]
even nowe w
th
in [.]
informed hir Ma
tie
of [.]
S
t
Malloes
and [Nantes] [.]
fol.140v
Belgia: 1591. May
[Munez], whoe sent three shippes from
Middelborowgh,
of w
ch
man, [ses] the being made heare what he showld be, will heare
that he is dead abowt the beginning of this moneth: and this man
had used this trade as it is informed from S
t
Malloes a longe time.
The Ambassado
r
also informeth us of a great nomber of shippes
above xx
ty
that weare laden w
th
Corne, and w
th
sum quantetie
of powder, w
ch
shippes comming thorowgh the Narrowe Seas,
weare reported that theare voiadge was part to
Caen,
and part
to
Diepe,
and so also theie weare wasted w
th
certaine men of
Holland under such pretence, but in vearie trewthe theie all
went into
Neuhaven,
and so to
Roan,
wheare before theare
arrival, Corne was at soe hie a price and soe scant, as
the vulgar people began to have mutined, and readie to have
opposed them selves against the Garrison. This and such
like frawdes and abuses doe soe greatlie offend hir Ma
tie
as she thinketh she hath Cawse to repent hir self, (and of that
minde are all hir
Counsell)
that ever she tooke the defence
of thos Cuntries against the K. of Spaigne, considering she seeth
that the great mainten
a
ce of his Armie this manie yeares in thos
Lowe Cuntries, have been by the common transportac
o
n & cariage
of victuels to them, and that by spetiall licesnse of the States
whoe as yt semeth professeth to doe the same for gaine of
monie, and for the same theie pretend thearew
th
to mainteine
their men of warre: But when hir Ma
tie
first tooke them into hir
protec
o
n uppon their request, they professed than to continew
Enmitie against the K. of Spaigne, and not to treate w
th
him
in anie sort w
th
owt the Quenes Consent: at w
ch
time theie
[.] made mention to except libertie for them to sell their victu-
els & other provisions to the Enemie, w
ch
if theie had done hir
Ma
tie
[.] Contract w
th
them, for as to treat w
th
the K.
of Spaigne [.] by the Contract, w
th
owt hir Ma
ties
[.] been done w
th
owt anie perill, so as now
fol.141r
Conclusion of peace had followed, soe this [.] of the
Ennemie bringeth manifest danger both to them selves, theare
and to hir Ma
tie
also in that the Ennemies Armie is theareby
mainteined, as for a manifest Example was seen at the
Siege of
Sluce,
wheare in the vearie sight of the
Erle of
Leicester
, the
D. of Parmas
Armie was victualed w
th
a great
nomber of shippes owt of Zeland. Of this matter much maie
be said to delate hir Ma
ties
just Cawse of misliking, The
further Consideration wheareof I leave yt unto yowe to prose-
cute as directlie and Conveniently yowe maie, whearebye to
worke sum redresse of thes disorders, and spetiallye to procure
Resoluc
o
n from
e
States Generall
and Counsell, for the Execuc
o
n
of thes Articles and Request
that weare made on hir Ma
ties
behalf to the late Deputies when theie weare heare of whose
Actions since their retorne, she mervaileth she wold never
heare from them nor from yowe. At this time I understand
Mons
r
de Caron
is appointed their Agent, in the place of
Ortell
dead, to whome thes letters are delivered at this time
bicauwse the letters from the States weare browght to hir Ma
tie
by him. And so by reason that I am fullye occupied heare
at my howse at
Theobald
,
hir Ma
tie
being heare w
th
mee, I
am forced to make an ende of this letter w
th
owt informing yo
w
of more perticularities w
ch
I cannot doe heare, as I might
at
London:
but heareafterward
as I maie retorne to London,
I will make yowe further acquainted.
From the Cort
at Theobald
this xij
th
of Maie. 1591./
Yo
r
last l
re
s that came to my hand
are of the [.] of this mo-
neth w
ch
came yesterdaie, at w
ch
time also I had letters of
the sixt of the moneth from
S
r
Edward Norris
, whearein he
affirmeth that he never delt wth the Magazyn of victuels in
Ostend, nor knewe of anie they had p.]
quantetie of [.] and [.]
that it is altogether [.]
w
th
owt medling wth anye [.]
fol.141v
Belgia: 1591: May.
that theie allowe him onelie fowre nobles a daie owt of the
Contribuc
o
n monie, w
ch
he findeth insufficient for his charge in a place
soe deare as yt it./ He also complaineth against the States of
Zeland, for breaking the Treatie of Contribuc
o
n, spoiling the Country
soe for their [.] proffitt, as at this time, theare is nothing, [.]
[.] for the Contribuc
o
n, of w
ch
his Complaintes, I require
yowe to informe the Counsell theare./ And for the former dowbt he
had of attempting sumthing against the place, he continueth in the
former dowbt, for that theare is great provision of Wagons made abowt
Gent,
and
Bridges,
and much powder sent to Gent, w
ch
cannot be
but for Ostend, or matters of
France.
And further
wee
he
hath had
intelligence from the
Admirall of the Fleete
that lieth before
Dunkirk
that the preparations ar directlie for Ostend, but nevertheles he is con-
tented when yt shall appeare manifestly that the preparations are for sum
other place, to retorne the newe Bandes to their former
s
rvices, or at the
least two of them, and reteine but one whilest the time is dowbtfull.
And from
Callis
S
r
Robart Sidneie
hath been advertised that the
Attempt is [.] [indeede] for Ostend, w
ch
had been taken in hand before
this time, if
Mons
r
La Motte
had not had a fall from his horse
and thearebie hurt, of w
ch
as soone as he can be recovered he is
to take that matter in hand, so as by thes occasi ons it maie appeare
theare is good Cawse whie hie Ma
tie
showld be ernest to have that
towne succored, both w
th
men, victuell, and Munic
o
n: of w
ch
three
the States theare have had soe little Care, as thowgh the towne had
not been thears./
Yo
r
verie Loving frend.
William Burghley
